Archives | RSS « Your sticker on a Chiquita banana | Joe D sells Zest to Avenues Bistro… » Thursday, July 1, 2010 Question of the Day The counter argument on tipping
Posted
by Jonathan Bender on Thu, Jul 1, 2010 at 11:00 AM click to enlarge
What
is the tipping etiquette for half service restaurants? Order at a
counter, but they bring it out to you and clean up after you. -- Kansas City Twitter user Half Monk .
In the no man's land between tip jars and check sleeves, the casual dining restaurant with table service is a dilemma for diners. It doesn't have to be if you look at the actual service being provided.
I've stood behind the counter and helped bring out dishes to diners in a quick-serve restaurant. Many didn't tip because I was not a traditional server. I was operating the cash register and was not responsible for getting them a refill. But I was still making sure their orders were correct and clearing their tables when they were done.
If there's a tip jar, you can wait until after your meal to decide what you're going to tip. There still is a service element involved. Base your tip on the difficulty of your order and whether the food came quickly. iTipping recommends 5 to 10 percent. I'd lean closer to 10 percent or above if your server goes out of his or her way.
On the flip side, if you're doing all the work, no tipping is necessary. A perfect example is Oklahoma Joe's. You pick up the food at the counter, fill your own drink, clear off your tray and pack up your own leftovers. If anything, you deserve a tip. And so here is a tip. Reheat your leftover seasoned fries on a nonstick skillet. Turn them frequently with a spatula or tongs to keep them from getting burned on one side.

I'm not going to tip, let the cheap bastards that own the place pony up and pay a decent wage. report 0 likes, 0 dislikes like dislike Posted by Pete on 07/01/2010 at 3:39 PM I work for tips and when I am not working for tips I write about working for tips. At the risk of greatly upsetting my tip karma, I look at the standard differently.
There are two reasons to tip: 1) Service 2) The Government has deemed that employers can pay their certain positions half of the minimum wage with the expectation that these people receive the difference in tips. This savings to the employer is passed on to the guest through lower food prices. This subsidy on the price of the food is made up for by the guest's tip provided to the server.
I am not sure why an employee making over the minimum wage is entitled to the half as much as a traditional server for bringing the food to the table and clearing the plates after I leave. In a full service restaurant the server who makes 15-20% and half minimum wage pays the food runner or busser out of their tip. This is particularly true if the person who receives the tip is not the one who took the order and you have to get your own refills. Most places I see set up like this have one person running the food and another on the register. Therefore the difficulty of your order, it's accuracy, and it's speed are most likely not primarily controlled by the person bringing your food to the table.
That being said, I still tip at these places. It is not a sense of obligation, but a reward for good service. I feel it is always best to err on the side of courtesy to a fellow human. Still, I worry that obligatory tipping to everyone with a tip jar creates a resentment that harms the professionals that provide outstanding service, depend on tips for their income, and take a mandatory pay cut to subsidize the price of a guest's meal. report 0 likes, 0 dislikes like dislike Posted by Savvy Dave on 07/01/2010 at 3:06 PM Absolutely tip the carhops.
